Incident.Summary: Driver was stopped for an inoperative headlight. Odor of marijuana and an alcoholic beverage was detected. Driver performed SFST to unsatisfactory standards. Driver was arrested for DUI. A search of the vehicle revealed 5.4grams of marijuana.

AddressCommonName.CommonPlaceName: SB 13 / JUST NORTH OF PEGGY NECK

IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText: Maryland State Police TPR J. Hicks, IBM 7576 February 6th, 2023 MSP Patrol Vehicle: X-16 is a marked, black, Ford Explorer that is equipped with a functioning camera. I am equipped with a body worn camera that was also activated during the stop. BWC: https://mdsp.evidence.com/axon/evidence?evidence_id=597452e7b24e47cc8c974ea06aa3b3a3partner_id=5ed6a168304e40eb9a0cfb1a226ef1a1 Stop Location: Southbound US RT 13 just south of Stewart neck Rd, Somerset County, MD Driver/Defendant: Michael James Borland Date of Birth: 08/09/1993 DE SDX:2100811 Tracking Number:2Z42216155 (Civil citation) DUI Citation #:00S0YXJ, 00T0YXJ Officers Training/Experience *Trained in administering Standardized Field Sobriety Tests through the Eastern Shore Criminal Justice Academy and National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA). 2015. * Trained in administering Standardized Field Sobriety Tests through the Maryland State Police and National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA).2022. * Trained and certified to operate Radar and Lidar through the Maryland State Police. *NHTSA certified in Advanced Roadside Impaired Driving Enforcement (A.R.I.D.E). * CDS detection, recognition, packaging, distribution, classification and indicator training from ESCJA police academy (2015) and Maryland State Police Academy (2022). * Gangs 101 * Numerous CDS arrests and convictions in Wicomico County, Maryland Courts as a previous Police Officer/ Detective with the Salisbury Police Department. Processing: Marijuana seized 5.7 grams Narrative: This report has been prepared based upon the observations of this trooper and/or those of other troopers relative to the offense(s). The facts contained herein are intended solely to give the prosecuting authority a basic understanding of the facts pertaining to this case. The facts contained herein are not intended to be an exhaustive recitation of the facts pertaining to pretrial or trial issues. Instead, this trooper anticipates that during the pretrial proceedings in this case, the prosecutor will take the opportunity to interview this trooper in order to ascertain any and all relevant facts which might be the subject of this troopers testimony during court proceedings. Assignment: On February 6th, 2023 I was working a night shift patrol assignment in Somerset County, Maryland. Phase I: Vehicle in motion On 02/06/2023, I was on duty in official capacity as a Maryland State Trooper operating marked MSP vehicle X-16 conducting stationary patrol in the area of S/B US RT 13 near Eden Allen Rd. While conducting patrol, I observed a vehicle traveling southbound on US RT 13 towards Eden Allen Rd in lane 2. I further observed this vehicle to have an inoperative front headlamp. I began to follow the vehicle and observed it to be a 2010, Silver, Mercury Mariner bearing Delaware registration: PC248759. I activated my emergency equipment (front and rear lights) and conducted a traffic stop on the vehicle at 2250 hours. Phase II: Personal Contact and Probable cause search I approached the driver side front window and made contact with the driver and sole occupant of the vehicle identified asMichael James Borland. While speaking with Borland, I immediately detected a strong odor of raw marijuana emanating from the passenger compartment of the vehicle. I knew this to be Marijuana, a schedule I controlled dangerous substance through my training knowledge and experience as a police officer. I could also smell a faint odor of an alcoholic beverage emanating from Borlands breath that was being overpowered by the strong odor of marijuana. As Borland was retrieving the documents that I requested (drivers license/ registration card), I observed his eyes to be glassy and for him to have a glazed look/expression on his face. While Borland was looking through his documents I asked him Where are you headed to tonight. Borland advised he was headed to pick up his son. Once I retrieved the requested documents, I returned to my patrol vehicle and requested for additional Troopers to assist. TFC Maggio and STPR Brown arrived on scene to assist. I then requested Borland to exit the vehicle for a probable cause search based on the odor of marijuana. Borland complied and exited the vehicle without incident. Borland walked around the front of his vehicle and then along the side of the vehicle to reach the area between my patrol vehicle and his vehicle. While walking, Borland appeared to have stumbled and bumped into his vehicle with his left shoulder. Borland remained with STPR Brown throughout the search of his vehicle. While searching the vehicle, I located the following items: - One (1), clear plastic bag containing marijuana. 5.7 grams. Located in the center console. Later verified by SGT Schur. - One (1), opened, half drank bottle of Espolon Tequila. Located in the center console. After completing this search, I was informed by STPR Brown that he detected the odor of an alcoholic beverage emanating from the breath of Borland. I then met with Borland and observed a wet spot (fresh liquid spill stain), on the upper front right portion of his green zip up jacket. It should be noted other than the open bottle of Tequila, no other beverage containers were located within the vehicle. I did locate two red WaWa cups that were stacked together. After observing them i did not observe them to have liquid within them nor were they warm to the touch indicating a warm beverage was recently within it. I then requested for Borland to submit to Standardized Field Sobriety Tests (SFST). Phase III: Pre Arrest Screening: STANDARDIZED FIELD SOBRIETY TESTS (SFST) Conditions/pre test questions: This testing was conducted on a flat/level portion of the roads shoulder directly in front of my patrol vehicle. The roadway was illuminated by my patrol vehicles headlamps. The roadway had no foreign debris or tripping hazards that would impede this testing process. The weather was clear with a temperature of approximately 30 degrees Farenheit. Prior to conducting any testing, I deactivated my patrol vehicles front facing emergency lights. Also, no other patrol vehicles front facing emergency lights were activated. Prior to conducting testing, I asked him if he had any problems with his vision. He stated no. I asked Borland if he wore glasses. He stated no. I asked Borland if he took any medication. He stated no. I then asked Borland if he could see the tip of my finger (right index finger). He advised that he could. I then asked Borland to touch the tip of my finger with the tip of his right index finger. Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus: 6 out of 6 clues 1. Borland displayed lack of smooth pursuit in both eyes. 2. Borland displayed distinct and sustained nystagmus at maximum deviation in both eyes. 3. Borland displayed the onset of nystagmus prior to 45 degrees in both eyes. Note: Borland also displayed vertical gaze nystagmus (VGN) in both eyes. Walk and Turn: 6 out of 8 clues Borland was instructed to put his left foot down, and to put his right foot heel to toe in front of his left with his arms at his sides. I then completed a demonstration of the walk and turn test only doing 3 steps for demonstration purposes. I asked if Borland understood the instructions, and he advised that he did. Instructional Phase: - Started the test prior to being instructed to do so. (CLUE 1) Walking Phase - Missed heel to toe by more than one half inch. (CLUE 2) - Stepped offline to the left. (CLUE 3). - Raised right arm more than 6 inches away from body on step 2-9 on initial walk. Then again on steps 1-9 on return walk. (CLUE 4) - Improper turn. Completed a spinning style turn to the right instead of completing a series of small steps as instructed. (CLUE 5) - Stopped once started. Had to be reminded how to complete the test after he completed 9 steps. (CLUE 6) One Leg Stand: 4 out of 4 clues Prior to completing the testing, I provided instruction and completed a demonstration of the test. Borland advised he understood the test and had no questions. Immediately upon beginning the test, Borland squatted down bending his right knee to approximately a 45-degree angle with his arms extended out at his sides parallel to the ground (depicted below). I immediately stopped Borland and corrected this prior to continuing the test. base64," style="height:117px; margin:5px 10px; width:175px" /> Throughout the test. I observed the following clues: - Borlands body swayed to the right as he was re-positioning himself to start after being corrected for squatting down. He raised his arms to prevent falling over. (CLUE 1) - Borland used his arms to balance numerous times throughout this test. His arms were extended out at his sides similar to the above picture. (CLUE 2) - On count 15, Borland lost his balance, hopped to the right putting his foot down while stepping to the side with his arms raised to avoid falling over. (CLUES 3 and 4) Based on my observations and Borlands poor performance on the offered field sobriety test, I placed him under arrest at 2305 hours. Borland was placed in double locked handcuffs and secured in the front right seat of my patrol vehicle. Once at the barrack, Borlandwas provided a copy of the DR-15 to read along as I read it aloud. Throughout my reading of the DR15, Borland talked over top of me and interrupted me numerous time. I read the DR 15 to him verbatim at 2344 hours. He signed the form, however refused to submit to the Intoximeter test. SGT Schur a certified Intoximeter operator, was readily available to administer the test. Borland was issued traffic citations and provided copies of all forms that he signed. Borland was released from the MSP princess Anne barrack to a sober friend (Sade Patrice Williams). Based on the above listed facts, I request this case be closed by arrest. All events occurred in Somerset County, Maryland.

IncidentProperty.Description: One, clear plastic bag containing 5.7 grams of marijuana.
